document.title: Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills for Career and Technical Education

5C31BBB2890C470AA3724787B2514F3F.description:
create a clear and coherent oral presentation that analyzes the results of an accounting
simulation covering an accounting cycle and includes the use of correct grammar,
spelling, punctuation, and citation of resource materials.

4A33F2CE4BF048C7997E32681423DC48.description: engage in an accounting simulation covering an accounting cycle;

41790C8EE251430F900060C42EC2C713.description:
use accounting technology, including discussing the use of data mining and integrating
technology into accounting;

4DF118DB17A14966B30DAC9FB070B7D8.description:
The student accesses, processes, maintains, evaluates, and disseminates financial information to
assist business decision making. The student is expected to:

AA0E2C6DBEAC406F9C19B2F369D70321.description: determining which laws and regulations apply.

C83AA6DE37264CCEAEE38469CB48C4FF.description: evaluating the validity and reliability of those sources;

D8CD9E9A8834458BBAA70870CC345F79.description: formulating questions to analyze the issue;

81BEAB991E694FFBA77BD22A00D63413.description:
identify and research a case study involving a historically significant compliance or
regulatory issue that led to the formation of regulatory agencies or laws, including:

11BB0B7509BE4F509404A27A8D42D7F9.description: discuss state regulation of the accounting industry;

F7E0C70212174A49932AE4665304F635.description:
describe the role of the Securities and Exchange Commission in regulating the accounting
industry;

8FBD152C07A44E389A856F601C9FEEB5.description:
describe the impact of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 on internal controls and financial
reporting;

2F60F17F4E3F4952AB414A4C6379B47D.description:
The student describes laws and regulations in order to manage business operations and
transactions in accounting. The student is expected to:

286C99F5AE514D9EA35E5CF71F41324F.description:
identify and perform tax accounting functions such as recordkeeping procedures and the
nature of corporate tax accounting.

512A4ECC8BC544F280BA1603140D36AB.description:
understand that internal accounting controls exist to ensure the proper recording of
financial transactions;

57AA23D3C7034A369F6691822DC6A5DF.description:
complete a work sheet for a corporation, including calculating adjustments for
depreciation, merchandise inventory, and federal taxes;

2F94421AE6234DE296AA00C2199BA5B6.description: analyze the articles of incorporation needed to start a corporation;

EF4EC71474D2482D8F1151FB06F97D83.description:
The student performs specialized accounting functions for a corporation and completes an
accounting cycle. The student is expected to:

E99FFB19DC1046AFA92450E4273BB908.description:
analyze the impact of salary expenses and payroll tax expense on total expenses and net
income.

99223336284B4C4693130201364642F4.description: discuss payroll tax expense forms and reports;

90B37C790020418C8A7E66D85E35C6E0.description: calculate employee earnings, including gross earnings, withholdings, and net pay;

1A20A28A470543EA963473542B7F0BF7.description: maintain employee earnings records and registers;

2BBA3F73BCD446F69581FC19D83FED8F.description: interpret time cards to calculate hours worked;

874A176F22074E7D83E235937D33386D.description:
The student completes payroll procedures to calculate, record, and distribute payroll earnings and
analyzes the impact of these expenses on a company's financial position. The student is expected
to:

7412211125554F7EAE013BCB4809C3DF.description:
analyze the results of valuing inventory under the FIFO method, LIFO method, weighted
average method, and the Gross Profit method of estimating inventory to determine the
effect on Net Income and Gross Profit.

13AB6CB1D0944F5CB0AA90485946DB95.description:
discuss the importance of merchandise inventory to a corporation, including the benefits
of determining the most efficient inventory levels;

C4DB54EF9CBF466EA292A0AC89129E2D.description:
The student investigates merchandise inventory to determine the impact on a company's financial
position. The student is expected to:

30005A3EB2F847EEA2CFB94FDD9CEFD6.description: analyze the impact of accounts receivable on the balance sheet and cash flow statements.

0ECC75CF11444A75943AE938D923F469.description: prepare a schedule of accounts receivable;

955E88ABF312433BA97BA473E132C82B.description: process sales orders, returns, and allowances;

8C151CCD9A154693A9EE022775105832.description: post to an accounts receivable subsidiary ledger;

11B49EE4B267407F8920EB8BB9A94A95.description: maintain a customer file for accounts receivable;

B6173F19E93A44C79E2AF76240027CE6.description: explain the nature of accounts receivable;

BAB203DC10F24DD1877E2941B2300B0D.description: The student performs accounts receivable functions. The student is expected to:

83927F577D654DBB980919D336E00AD0.description: analyze the impact of accounts payable on the balance sheet and cash flow statements.

D1141369D1344DEC81BC5E11E6CC62B8.description: prepare a schedule of accounts payable;

5D0ED7C659C34EC085C4A5E823FCB709.description: post to an accounts payable subsidiary ledger;

B26AEC6BF6ED49EDA1EA919609ADB7BB.description: The student performs accounts payable functions. The student is expected to:

B0B5CC378D204E97B3D125132DF83821.description:
The student performs accounting functions for a merchandising business. The student is expected
to explain the nature of special journals and recording transactions in special journals.

30C90967138141AF918488E755EA6D67.description: explain the benefits of electronic funds transfer.

7B114EBD4C6E45B7A7B4A77E39BC8708.description: journalize and post entries related to banking activities;

DB5331CF920F4D7EB2EBFBA730D2A724.description: journalize and post entries to establish and replenish petty cash;

A1963371ED234B239265EEFEBC0F73F3.description: prove cash and reconcile bank statements;

E5A1FE76F55045B1AF00909716C7A3E1.description:
explain cash control procedures such as bank account access, dual control, timely account
reconciliations, and security of check stock;

330C362AB9E94F1E913636EAADF0DBE2.description: The student analyzes cash controls. The student is expected to:

14D85DF7FA9740C59849FCDA034041AE.description:
prepare financial statements, including income statements, balance sheets, statements of
stockholders' equity, and changes in owners' equity.

6112072BB77841D58195C994B813D5CE.description: journalize and post adjusting and closing entries;

D62827662F594B2685F8864453C6F45A.description: post journal entries to general ledger accounts;

36BE3DC5042F443094C2787E79B5BEBE.description: journalize transactions in a general journal;

C922A15B59B84A6F977CB53CD301B637.description:
analyze the effects of transactions on the accounting equation and use T accounts to
analyze transactions;

DC73FBBB99FB47C7B1B908B4930EE869.description:
The student uses equations, graphical representations, accounting tools, strategies, and automated
systems in real-world situations to maintain, monitor, control, and plan the use of financial
resources. The student will complete an accounting cycle for a service business. The student is
expected to:

FA8E6D3E7A2549F0B218DB1640533248.description:
identify accounting licensing and certification programs, including professional
designations for accountants such as certified public accountant and certified
management accountant.

31250A1065D4483ABCEFECD4B8B52A8D.description:
explore careers in accounting, including education requirements, roles, and
responsibilities of certified public accountants, general ledger accountants, management
accountants, auditors, government accountants, international accountants, forensic
accountants, and senior management in accounting;

40BC120C01B246E99FD4322F423A6B91.description:
discuss the significance of responsibility in accounting such as ethical and social
responsibility;

5CDF87EBD00D4F18A67F38489488180D.description:
The student uses career planning concepts, tools, and strategies to explore accounting careers. The
student is expected to:

6EABE16047424074B1406C584A4A8E1F.description: describe the purpose of accounting and financial reporting;

2E83CE8AB5D44FDE969308E4A4987367.description:
The student communicates an understanding of the accounting industry. The student is expected
to:

F8A26E5FFE0C4B36913ED41D312B5EA9.description: demonstrate attention to detail in completed assignments;

486F28ACE9FF446185F81F083BC7DE60.description: demonstrate an understanding of integrity and strong work ethic;

982267B95CB8423F85CBD180BE842FCB.description: demonstrate effective oral and written communication skills;

E5C8F93E70E44B0888F1B691147CEC71.description:
The student demonstrates professional standards/employability skills as required by business and
industry. The student is expected to:

5282E96649D1491A91C8CE80867091C7.description:
Statements that contain the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those
containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

AE8292251C5B4878A4F75BD362471D0A.description:
Students are encouraged to participate in extended learning experiences such as career and
technical student organizations and other leadership or extracurricular organizations.

4EE021ED4C3D44ADA11239D28E66CB57.description:
In Accounting I, students will investigate the field of accounting, including how it is impacted by
industry standards as well as economic, financial, technological, international, social, legal, and
ethical factors. Students will reflect on this knowledge as they engage in the process of recording,
classifying, summarizing, analyzing, and communicating accounting information. Students will
formulate and interpret financial information for use in management decision making.

59603AEC79674639A7108C14D87BF216.description:
Accounting encompasses careers that record, classify, summarize, analyze, and communicate a
business's financial information/business transactions for use in management decision making.
Accounting includes such activities as bookkeeping, systems design, analysis, and interpretation
of accounting information.

DB4B326AC15D471094CF1BAD5563E850.description:
The Finance Career Cluster focuses on planning, services for financial and investment planning,
banking, insurance, and business financial management.

D4ADE9AFC24E4CF188AD6224605B3956.description:
Career and technical education instruction provides content aligned with challenging academic
standards and relevant technical knowledge and skills for students to further their education and
succeed in current or emerging professions.

DC0901C88F57452A85C7A66D2090EBFC.description:
General requirements. This course is recommended for students in Grades 10-12. Recommended
prerequisite: Principles of Business, Marketing, and Finance. Students shall be awarded one credit for
successful completion of this course.
